subject: Law
title: Toxic Substances Control Act
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Toxic Substances Control Act.

hook.text: There are over 86,000 chemicals in commerce. Most were never tested for safety before entering the market.

buildup.text: TSCA (1976) gives the EPA authority to regulate chemicals that pose unreasonable risks to health or the environment.

discovery.text: The 2016 Lautenberg Act reformed TSCA, requiring EPA to evaluate existing chemicals and make safety findings.

twist.text: The EU's REACH requires companies to prove chemicals are safe before selling. The US puts the burden on regulators.

climax.text: Asbestos was known to be deadly for decades. The EPA's ban was overturned in court. A full ban came only in 2024.

punchline.text: Chemicals are innocent until proven guilty in the US. Europe flips that rule.

quiz.question: How does the US approach to chemical safety differ from the EU's?
options: The EU requires companies to prove safety first
